awd_titl_txt: Statistical Mechanics of Non-Local Disordered Models Associated with Quantum LDPC codes
awd_abstract_narration:
Large-scale quantum computation is impossible without coherence. Quantum error correction (QEC) is therefore an important technique to protect coherence. QEC codes can enable quantum computers to tolerate occasional faults.  Topological QEC codes like Kitaev's surface code provide quantum error corrections with give relatively high fault-tolerant thresholds for scalable quantum computation.  However, they require a large overhead in the number of ancilla qubits.  The research in  this project aims to develop more general quantum low-density parity-check (LDPC) QEC codes which may work with smaller overhead.  This project will also explore statistical mechanics of classical and quantum spin models that are related to LDPC codes.  Understanding the stability of various phases and phase transitions in such physical models, both with and without disorder, will lead to better coherence protection techniques.  Another benefit will be improved understanding of the properties of quantum and classical models in curved spaces, e.g., due to background gravity.

In more technical terms, the PI will continue his studies of disordered spin models associated with decoding transition, related gauge models associated with fault-tolerant decoding, and quantum models with extensive ground state entropy, including U(1) gauge models. The focus of the research will be on the relations between differently defined transitions: the decoding transition, transitions defined in terms of a divergent specific heat, correlation length, domain wall tension, spin susceptibilities, area/perimeter law, etc, as well as transitions defined in terms of entanglement entropy, topological entropy, fidelity, and related information-theoretic quantities.   These results will be incorporated in a practical decoding algorithm for quantum LDPC codes.

por.por_cntn:
Publications supported by the grant elucidated the connection between
maximum-likelihood decoding of quantum stabilizer codes and the phase
diagram of associated spin models.  The connection is not absolute, as
for most code families the decoding transition can be suppressed by
removing a vanishing fraction of qubits, while the thermodynamical
limit may be defined solely in terms of intensive and specific
quantities.  For example, in the case of erasures, boundary of the
decodable phase is shown to coincide with the percolation threshold
when code distance grows faster than a logarithm of the code length,
and is asymptotically at zero for code families with sublogarithmic
distance scaling.

Second, new families of quantum error-correcting codes have been
constructed.  One of the families, the higher-dimensional
hypergraph-product codes, is a well known tensor product of chain
complexes.  The new result is the addition of the homological distance
to the characteristics given by the K"unneth theorem. 

In addition to coding theory applications, these results are relevant for the field of
computational homology, as well as for other applications where
methods of algebraic topology are used.

The open-source GAP software package QDistRnd
(https://qec-pages.github.io/QDistRnd/) implements a probabilistic
algorithm for finding the minimum distance of a q-ary quantum code linear
over a finite field GF(q), as well as a novel storage format for
associated matrices.  The format is based on the well established
MaTrix market eXchange (MTX) Coordinate format developed at NIST, and
is designed for full backward compatibility with this format. Thus,
the files are readable by any software package which supports MTX.
